An Efficient and Multi-private Key Secure Aggregation for Federated Learning

Abstract

With the emergence of privacy leaks in federated learning, secure aggregation protocols that mainly adopt either homomorphic encryption or threshold secret sharing have been widely developed for federated learning to protect the privacy of the local training data of each client. However, these existing protocols suffer from many shortcomings, such as the dependence on a trusted third party, the vulnerability to clients being corrupted, low efficiency, the trade-off between security and fault tolerance, etc. To solve these disadvantages, we propose an efficient and multi-private key secure aggregation scheme for federated learning. Specifically, we skillfully modify the variant ElGamal encryption technique to achieve homomorphic addition operation, which has two important advantages: 1) The server and each client can freely select public and private keys without introducing a trust third party and 2) Compared to the variant ElGamal encryption, the plaintext space is relatively large, which is more suitable for the deep model. Besides, for the high dimensional deep model parameter, we introduce a super-increasing sequence to compress multi-dimensional data into 1-D, which can greatly reduce encryption and decryption times as well as communication for ciphertext transmission. Detailed security analyses show that our proposed scheme achieves the semantic security of both individual local gradients and the aggregated result while achieving optimal robustness in tolerating both client collusion and dropped clients. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the accuracy of our scheme is almost the same as the non-private approach, while the efficiency of our scheme is much better than the state-of-the-art homomorphic encryption-based secure aggregation schemes. More importantly, the efficiency advantages of our scheme will become increasingly prominent as the number of model parameters increases.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, multi-private key secure aggregation, privacy-preserving, robustness against client collusion, fault tolerance.

1 Introduction

With the continued emergence of privacy leaks and data abuse, the flourishing of traditional centralized training, which collects a huge number of training data from distributed data providers, has been gradually impeded. As demonstrated in [1], data providers are no longer willing to upload local data for the consideration of personal privacy and data control right. Obviously, it is almost impossible to train a high-performance deep model without the huge training data. In order to eliminate privacy concerns of data providers, federated learning [2], as one of the most important research aspects of private computing [3], has recently been presented. Federated learning is a distributed framework, where many data providers (also called clients) collaboratively train a shared global model under the orchestration of a central server. Throughout the training processes, training data are always saved locally and clients only send the local gradient to the server. Obviously, under this training framework, the appearance of federated learning can address data abuse and greatly improve the data privacy of clients. Thereby, the research of federated learning has exploded in just a few years.

Unfortunately, recent works [4, 5, 6, 7] disclose that the adversary may still obtain some private information of training data or directly reconstruct training data from interacted model parameters or local gradient. Specifically, [4] and [5] explore the membership inference attack based on the model parameter to infer if a particular data record was included in the training dataset. [6] and [7] find that the adversary may reconstruct training data from the local gradient. To improve the security of federated learning, many privacy-preserving federated learning schemes [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16] have been presented. These schemes widely adopt two cryptographic techniques to achieve secure aggregation, i.e., the homomorphic encryption technique [17] or (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique [18], which ensures the privacy-preservation of the local gradient for each client. However, these related schemes suffer from the following disadvantages, which impede their application in practice:

  • â€¢

    For the schemes [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13] designed by the homomorphic encryption technique, all clients share a pair of public and private keys generated by the trusted third party and encrypt local gradient with the same public key. Obviously, once a client was compromised by the adversary, then this system is no longer secure, and meanwhile, no collusion is allowed in these schemes. Besides, these schemes suffer from a huge computational cost and communication overhead.

  • â€¢

    For the schemes [14, 15, 16] designed by the (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique, the storage costs of private double-masks for each client is proportional to the number of clients. Meanwhile, for different iterations, all clients have to re-select masked secrets and interactively perform the corresponding secret-sharing operation, which leads to extra interactive time and communication overhead. Besides, there is a trade-off between security (i.e., robustness against client collusion) and fault tolerance. If tğ‘¡t is relatively large (i.e., the robustness against client collusion is relatively high), then nâˆ’tğ‘›ğ‘¡n-t is small, so the number of dropped clients must be low since nâˆ’tğ‘›ğ‘¡n-t is small. On the contrary, the security is relatively low, i.e., if tğ‘¡t is small, then the system can only allow tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1 clients to collude (For the extreme case of t=2ğ‘¡2t=2, these schemes cannot allow client collusion). Furthermore, these secret sharing-based schemes do not consider the privacy preservation of the aggregated result. That is, any adversary (i.e., not just the server) could obtain the aggregated result once getting the transmitted data.

Therefore, designing an efficient secure aggregation scheme that supports client self-selected keys, robustness against collusion attacks, and fault tolerance robustness remains a challenge. To overcome this challenge, in this paper, we design an efficient and multi-private key secure aggregation scheme for federated learning, which supports homomorphic encryption with multi-private key, decryption limitation for the aggregated result, robustness against collusion attacks, and fault tolerance robustness. The main contributions of this paper are three aspects:

  • â€¢

    Considering the privacy preservation of the local gradient of each client and the aggregated result, we skillfully design a multi-private key secure aggregation protocol without introducing a trusted third party, which allows the server and each client to freely select a pair of public and private keys. Specifically, this protocol is modified based on the simplest additive homomorphic encryption (i.e., the variant ElGamal cryptosystem [19] and the corresponding encryption operation is (gr,gmâ€‹pâ€‹kr)superscriptğ‘”ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘”ğ‘šğ‘superscriptğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿ(g^{r},g^{m}pk^{r}), where pâ€‹k=gsâ€‹kğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘”ğ‘ ğ‘˜pk=g^{sk} is the public key computed by the private key sâ€‹kğ‘ ğ‘˜sk). Each clientâ€™s local gradient is encrypted by its own public key, which can ensure that even if the private keys of some clients are leaked, it will not affect the privacy of other clients. Thus, even if at most |S|âˆ’2ğ‘†2|S|-2 clients collude with the server (|S|ğ‘†|S| is the number of online clients), they cannot obtain the respective local gradient of the remaining two clients. Besides, only the server can decrypt the aggregated result with its own private key.

  • â€¢

    In order to ensure efficiency, we introduce a super-increasing sequence to greatly reduce the computational costs and communication overhead. Specifically, instead of encrypting each dimension of multidimensional model parameters one by one, our scheme uses this sequence to compress multidimensional gradients into 1-D and then encrypts this compressed data. Obviously, this design can greatly decrease the number of encryption and decryption operations (i.e., computational costs) and the number of transmitted ciphertexts (i.e., communication overhead). As we know, the variant ElGamal has high decryption complexity and is only suitable for the small message space. However, the introduction of the super-increasing sequence will greatly increase the length of the message space. As a result, we skillfully modify the encryption operation of the variant Elgamal to ensure the efficiency and correctness of the decryption.

  • â€¢

    Detailed security analyses demonstrate that our scheme can ensure the semantic security of the local gradient of each client and the aggregated result, robustness against collusion between the server and no more than |S|âˆ’2ğ‘†2|S|-2 clients, fault-tolerant robustness for up to Nâˆ’2ğ‘2N-2 clients. At the same time, extensive experiments demonstrate scheme exhibits significantly better communication and computational efficiency than the related secure aggregation work. Besides, the accuracy of our scheme is almost the same as the most popular federated learning scheme that does not consider privacy preservation (e.g., FedAvg [20]).

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. We describe models and design goals in Section 2. Then, we present our scheme in Section 3, followed by its security analysis and performance evaluation in Sections 4 and 5, respectively. Related work is discussed in Section 6. Finally, we conclude our work in Section 7.

2 Models and design goals

In this section, we first describe an FL system model and the corresponding threat model used in this paper, and then identify our design goals. Before describing in detail, we would like to give the description of the notations used in the proposed scheme in Table I.

2.1 System Model

As shown in most federated learning frameworks[21, 10, 22], federated learning is essentially a distributed machine learning framework, which allows clients to collaboratively train a global model under the orchestration of a central server without exchanging the local training data of each client. Therefore, our system comprises two types of entities: a server and a number of clients {ğ’1,ğ’2,â€¦,ğ’N}subscriptğ’1subscriptğ’2â€¦subscriptğ’ğ‘\{\mathcal{C}_{1},\mathcal{C}_{2},\ldots,\mathcal{C}_{N}\}, which are responsible for the following operations:

  • â€¢

    Server: The server is responsible for aggregating local gradients received from clients, updating the global model, and broadcasting the updated global model to clients for the next iteration.

  • â€¢

    Clients: Every client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} (iâˆˆ[1,N]ğ‘–1ğ‘i\in[1,N]) performs local model training with the global model received from the server and local training dataset to get local gradients. Then, ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} uploads the local gradients to the server for aggregation. It is worth noting that since the number of clients is relatively large, we cannot guarantee that all clients can participate in each iteration, especially for mobile or IoT devices with unreliable connections. That is, the dropped devices happen frequently [23].

Furthermore, as illustrated in Fig. 1, the traditional framework of federated learning allows the server and clients to perform the following two phases cooperatively until the model converges:

  1. 1.

    Local model training: The server first broadcasts the current global model parameter Wğ‘ŠW to all clients. Then, each client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} computes local gradients âˆ‡isubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–\nabla_{i} with the received Wğ‘ŠW and local training data ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} by running the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm. After that, ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} uploads âˆ‡isubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–\nabla_{i} to the server for model update.

  2. 2.

    Global model aggregation and update: The server first performs the weighted average aggregation operation for received local gradients, and then updates the current model Wğ‘ŠW for the next iteration. Specifically, given the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta, the aggregation and update operations are shown as:

    Wâ‡Wâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆSa|ğ’Ÿi||ğ’Ÿ|â€‹âˆ‡iâŸAggregationâŸUpdateâ‡ğ‘ŠsubscriptâŸğ‘Šğœ‚subscriptâŸsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ’Ÿsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–AggregationUpdateW\Leftarrow\underbrace{W-\eta\underbrace{\sum_{i\in S_{a}}\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|}{|\mathcal{D}|}\nabla_{i}}_{\mathrm{Aggregation}}}_{\mathrm{Update}} (1)

2.2 Threat Model

In this paper, two kinds of adversaries are considered in our threat model, i.e., internal adversary and external eavesdropper, and the corresponding attack capabilities are defined as follows:

  • â€¢

    Internal adversary: An internal adversary can be the server or the client. Similar to most privacy-preserving federated learning schemes[24, 16], both the server and clients are assumed to be honest and curious, which means that they honestly follow the underlying scheme, but are curious about the private training data of each client. More specifically, the server or the client tries to obtain the local gradients of a specific client in order to obtain the corresponding local training data through private attacks, such as reconstruction attacks [6]. Furthermore, in order to enhance the attack capability, the server may collude with some clients to jointly obtain the local gradients of other clients. Specifically, these colluded clients may share some private values in the hope of helping to obtain the local training data of a specific non-colluded client.

  • â€¢

    External eavesdropper: An external eavesdropper tries to obtain the local training data of a specific client by eavesdropping on the contents communicated between the server and clients.

2.3 Design Goals

Based on the above system model and threat model, we intend to achieve the following goals in the proposed scheme:

  • â€¢

    Privacy-preservation: Neither the server nor the clients can access the private training data of any particular client, even if they collude. Specifically, we should ensure that neither the server nor the clients can obtain the local gradients of any particular client even if some curious clients collude with the server. Furthermore, another goal is that we consider the privacy-preservation of the aggregated result (i.e., the global model). More specifically, our scheme ensures that only the server can decrypt the aggregated gradient and obtain the well-trained model. At the same time, external eavesdroppers cannot obtain more private information than internal attackers.

  • â€¢

    Efficiency and fault tolerance: Apart from the privacy-preservation requirement, efficiency including computation, communication, and model accuracy is one of the most important metrics for federated learning [25], especially for mobile or IoT devices[26]. In fact, the application of privacy-preserving technology will inevitably bring efficiency loss. Therefore, minimizing efficiency loss as much as possible is also our design goal. Furthermore, as shown in 2.1, the robustness of fault tolerance needs to be considered due to the system heterogeneity in federated learning.

3 Proposed scheme

In this section, we present our secure aggregation scheme for federated learning in detail. According to the traditional workflow of federated learning and the privacy-preserving goals, our secure aggregation scheme mainly includes three steps: 1) system parameter initialization, 2) local model training and encryption, and 3) model aggregation and decryption, which is highlighted in red in Fig. 1. Roughly speaking, before federated model training, the system parameters need to be generated. After that, each client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} performs the local training under the orchestration of the server. More specifically, given the global model Wğ‘ŠW, ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} computes the local gradient âˆ‡isubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–\nabla_{i}, and then encrypts it with its own private key sâ€‹kiğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–sk_{i}. Finally, ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} uploads the encrypted gradient, denoted as Eâ€‹(âˆ‡i)ğ¸subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–E(\nabla_{i}), to the server. In what follows, the server aggregates the received Eâ€‹(âˆ‡i)ğ¸subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–E(\nabla_{i}) and decrypts the aggregation result with the help of online clients. After that, the server uploads the current model Wğ‘ŠW according to Eq. (1). The overall flow of our algorithm is shown in Algorithm 1, where the detailed operation of each step will be presented in the following.

3.2 Model training and encryption

As described in Section 2.1, we cannot guarantee that all clients can participate in each iteration. Thus, we should determine which clients can participate in the current iteration before executing model training. A simple approach is that each client sends a 1-bit message to the server to prove itâ€™s online. 3.3 Model aggregation and decryption

After receiving the encrypted gradients from clients, the server first aggregates them and then decrypts the aggregated result by interacting with clients. After that, the server updates the current model Wğ‘ŠW for the next iteration. In what follows, we describe the above operations in detail.

3.4 Extension

As we all know, the dimension of the deep model parameter is huge, so it is almost impossible to compress such high-dimensional data into one at a time due to the limitation of message space in the encryption algorithm. Therefore, in this section, we extend our scheme to prevent overflows in ciphertext additions.

More specifically, if the merged data âˆ‡^i>psubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘\widehat{\nabla}_{i}>p, then we can split âˆ‡i=(âˆ‡iâ€‹1,âˆ‡iâ€‹2,â€¦,âˆ‡iâ€‹n)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–1subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–2â€¦subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘›\nabla_{i}=(\nabla_{i1},\nabla_{i2},\ldots,\nabla_{in}) into multiple small segments and compress each segment into the 1-D data by the super-increasing vector ğšğš\mathbf{a}, denoted as âˆ‡^i=(âˆ‡^iâ€‹1,âˆ‡^iâ€‹2,â‹¯,âˆ‡^iâ€‹u)subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–1subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–2â‹¯subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘¢\widehat{\nabla}_{i}=(\widehat{\nabla}_{i1},\widehat{\nabla}_{i2},\cdots,\widehat{\nabla}_{iu}), where âˆ‡^iâ€‹j=a1â€‹âˆ‡i,jâ€‹kâˆ’k+1+a2â€‹âˆ‡i,jâ€‹kâˆ’k+2+â‹¯+akâ€‹âˆ‡i,jâ€‹k<psubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘1subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘2subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘˜2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘\widehat{\nabla}_{ij}=a_{1}\nabla_{i,jk-k+1}+a_{2}\nabla_{i,jk-k+2}+\cdots+a_{k}\nabla_{i,jk}<p for jâˆˆ[1,u]ğ‘—1ğ‘¢j\in[1,u] and u=âŒˆnkâŒ‰ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘˜u=\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil is the number of split segments. To this end, the difference between the basic version and the extension is that in the system initialization, the server needs to generate uğ‘¢u pairs of private and public keys, denoted as Î±â†’=(Î±1,Î±2,â‹¯,Î±u)â†’ğ›¼subscriptğ›¼1subscriptğ›¼2â‹¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘¢\vec{\alpha}=(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\cdots,\alpha_{u}) and Î²â†’=(Î²1,Î²2,â‹¯,Î²u)â†’ğ›½subscriptğ›½1subscriptğ›½2â‹¯subscriptğ›½ğ‘¢\vec{\beta}=(\beta_{1},\beta_{2},\cdots,\beta_{u}) where Î²i=gÎ±isubscriptğ›½ğ‘–superscriptğ‘”subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\beta_{i}=g^{\alpha_{i}}, and then sends the system parameter SysPara=(p,q,ğ”¾,g,Î²â†’,ğš)SysParağ‘ğ‘ğ”¾ğ‘”â†’ğ›½ğš\mathrm{SysPara}=(p,q,\mathbb{G},g,\vec{\beta},\mathbf{a}) to clients.

After computing the local gradient âˆ‡isubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–\nabla_{i}, each client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} compresses âˆ‡isubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–\nabla_{i} into âˆ‡^isubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–\widehat{\nabla}_{i}, and then conducts the encryption function ğ„ğ§ğœâ€‹(âˆ‡i,pâ€‹kS,SysPara)ğ„ğ§ğœsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘†SysPara\mathbf{Enc}(\nabla_{i},pk_{S},\mathrm{SysPara}) to obtain Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^i)=(Eiâ€‹1,Eiâ€‹2)ğ¸subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptğ¸ğ‘–1subscriptğ¸ğ‘–2E(\widehat{\nabla}_{i})=(E_{i1},E_{i2}), where Eiâ€‹1=(Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^iâ€‹1),Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^iâ€‹2),â€¦,Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^iâ€‹u))subscriptğ¸ğ‘–1ğ¸subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–1ğ¸subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–2â€¦ğ¸subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘¢E_{i1}=(E(\widehat{\nabla}_{i1}),E(\widehat{\nabla}_{i2}),\ldots,E(\widehat{\nabla}_{iu})) and Eiâ€‹2subscriptğ¸ğ‘–2E_{i2} are generated as:

{Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^iâ€‹j)=(p+1)âˆ‡^iâ€‹jâ‹…Î²jriâ€‹1modp2,fâ€‹oâ€‹râ€‹jâˆˆ[1,u]Eiâ€‹2=(griâ€‹2modp,griâ€‹1â‹…(pâ€‹kS)riâ€‹2modp)\left\{\begin{aligned} E(\widehat{\nabla}_{ij})&=(p+1)^{\widehat{\nabla}_{ij}}\cdot\beta_{j}^{r_{i1}}\mod p^{2},~{}~{}for~{}~{}j\in[1,u]\\ E_{i2}&=(g^{r_{i2}}\mod{p},g^{r_{i1}}\cdot(pk_{S})^{r_{i2}}\mod{p})\end{aligned}\right.

Then, the remaining steps are almost the same as the Section 3.3 in the basic version. Obviously, in this case, the number of ciphertexts is ğ®+ğŸğ®2\mathbf{u+2}. It is worth noting that we can directly use the original variant ElGamal to encrypt âˆ‡^i=(âˆ‡^iâ€‹1,âˆ‡^iâ€‹2,â‹¯,âˆ‡^iâ€‹u)subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–1subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–2â‹¯subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘¢\widehat{\nabla}_{i}=(\widehat{\nabla}_{i1},\widehat{\nabla}_{i2},\cdots,\widehat{\nabla}_{iu}) as (griâ€‹j,gâˆ‡^iâ€‹jâ‹…(pâ€‹kS)riâ€‹j)superscriptğ‘”subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—â‹…superscriptğ‘”subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘†subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—(g^{r_{ij}},g^{\widehat{\nabla}_{ij}}\cdot(pk_{S})^{r_{ij}}) for jâˆˆ[1,u]ğ‘—1ğ‘¢j\in[1,u], which can still be decrypted correctly by our decryption function. Obviously, the number of ciphertexts generated in this way is ğŸâ€‹ğ®2ğ®\mathbf{2u}, which is larger than ğ®+ğŸğ®2\mathbf{u+2} when u>2ğ‘¢2u>2. Therefore, our skillful modification has the following two advantages:

  • â€¢

    Only the server can decrypt the aggregated result, which is more secure than the secret sharing-based schemes that do not consider protecting the aggregated result.

  • â€¢

    For deep models with large-scale parameters (i.e., uğ‘¢u is relatively large), computational costs and communication overhead are greatly reduced compared to the naive encryption algorithm.

4 Security and fault tolerance analysis

In this section, we first analyze the security properties of our scheme and then show the robustness of fault tolerance.

4.1 Security analysis

In particular, following the design goals illustrated in Section 2.3, our security analysis includes three aspects: 1) The privacy-preservation of individual local gradient; 2) The privacy-preservation of aggregated result; 3) The robustness against collusion.

4.1.1 Privacy-preservation of individual local gradient

In this part, we focus on how our proposed scheme can prevent both the internal adversary (the server and curious clients) and the external eavesdropper from obtaining the local gradient of a particular client. Before describing in detail, we would like to give some related complexity assumptions [29], which support the security proof of our scheme.

Definition 1 (Discrete Logarithm (DL) Problem).

4.1.2 Privacy-preservation of aggregated result

As far as we know, many state-of-the-art secure aggregated works [14],[30] do not consider the privacy-preservation of the aggregated result. In other words, the aggregated results can also be obtained by any adversary other than the server, such as eavesdroppers or curious clients, as long as they have access to the uploaded data. In this paper, our designed scheme can avoid this situation to ensure that only the server can decrypt the aggregated encrypted gradient.

Theorem 2.

The aggregated gradient is semantically secure against the chosen-plaintext attack launched by curious clients or eavesdroppers under the DDH assumption.

Proof.

Suppose an adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} (e.g., eavesdroppers or curious clients) can obtain the data communicated between each client and the server. In this case, ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} can obtain pâ€‹kSğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘†pk_{S}, Rğ‘…R and {Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^i),Ti}ğ’iâˆˆSsubscriptğ¸subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†\{E(\widehat{\nabla}_{i}),T_{i}\}_{\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S}. Obviously, ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} can perform the aggregation function ğ€ğ ğ â€‹(Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^i),Ti)â†’(EAâ€‹gâ€‹g,d,T)â†’ğ€ğ ğ ğ¸subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–subscriptğ¸ğ´ğ‘”ğ‘”ğ‘‘ğ‘‡\mathbf{Agg}(E(\widehat{\nabla}_{i}),T_{i})\rightarrow(E_{Agg},d,T), and compute d/Tğ‘‘ğ‘‡d/T to get gâˆ‘ğ’iâˆˆSriâ€‹1superscriptğ‘”subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1g^{\sum_{\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S}r_{i1}}. Thus, the crux is that given (p+1)âˆ‘ğ’iâˆˆSâˆ‡^iâ‹…gÎ±â€‹âˆ‘ğ’iâˆˆSriâ€‹1â‹…superscriptğ‘1subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–superscriptğ‘”ğ›¼subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1(p+1)^{\sum\nolimits_{\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S}\widehat{\nabla}_{i}}\cdot g^{\alpha{\sum\nolimits_{\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S}r_{i1}}} and gâˆ‘ğ’iâˆˆSriâ€‹1superscriptğ‘”subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1g^{\sum_{\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S}r_{i1}}, whether ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} can recover (p+1)âˆ‘ğ’iâˆˆSâˆ‡^isuperscriptğ‘1subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–(p+1)^{\sum\nolimits_{\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S}\widehat{\nabla}_{i}}. Obviously, this problem can be attributed to the DDH problem. Therefore, similar to the proof of Theorem 1, the value (p+1)âˆ‘ğ’iâˆˆSâˆ‡^iâ‹…gÎ±â€‹âˆ‘ğ’iâˆˆSriâ€‹1â‹…superscriptğ‘1subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–superscriptğ‘”ğ›¼subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1(p+1)^{\sum\nolimits_{\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S}\widehat{\nabla}_{i}}\cdot g^{\alpha{\sum\nolimits_{\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S}r_{i1}}} meets the semantically secure under the DDH assumption. The details of the proof are omitted due to the page limitation. âˆ

It is worth noting that with this advantage, our scheme can ensure when the model is well-trained, only the server can know the well-trained model and can provide the prediction service 222During the model training, the server sends the encrypted model Wiâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W^{*}_{i} to each client ğ’iâˆˆSsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘†\mathcal{C}_{i}\in S and only the client in Sğ‘†S can decrypt the symmetric ciphertext to obtain Wğ‘ŠW (i.e., other offline clients and eavesdroppers cannot get Wğ‘ŠW). Although these clients can obtain the global model Wğ‘ŠW, this model is the result of an intermediate process rather than the final well-trained model. Thus, its leakage will not affect the final result too much. . This situation happens widely in the real world. For example, when the server is a service provider and clients are data providers, the server wants to provide some prediction services under a well-trained deep model. Obviously, this well-trained deep model is a profitable tool, which needs to be protected from disclosure. But the prerequisite is that the server needs to pay a certain amount of remuneration to ask the data provider to help generate this model. Obviously, data providers will not allow their own training data to be leaked, because training data is their asset and involves their privacy. For example, the training architecture of the privileged party is introduced in [31], in which the privileged party dominates the model training, and only the privileged party can recover the final model. Obviously, in our scheme, the server is equivalent to the privileged party.

4.1.3 Robustness against collusion

As set in the Threat model, in order to enhance the attack capability, the server may collude with some clients to jointly obtain the local gradients of other clients. Thus, in this part, we show how our scheme can defend against collusion between the server and curious clients.

Theorem 3.

Our scheme can ensure the privacy-preservation of the individual local gradient as long as any two online clients do not collude, i.e., our scheme can resist collusion between the server and up to any Nâˆ’2ğ‘2N-2 clients.

Proof.

Without loss of generality, we suppose two online clients ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} and ğ’jsubscriptğ’ğ‘—\mathcal{C}_{j} do not collude, and the remaining Nâˆ’2ğ‘2N-2 clients collude with the server to try to obtain the local gradients of ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} and ğ’jsubscriptğ’ğ‘—\mathcal{C}_{j}. As proved in Theorem 1, neither the server nor the client can obtain âˆ‡^isubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–\widehat{\nabla}_{i} or âˆ‡^jsubscript^âˆ‡ğ‘—\widehat{\nabla}_{j} from Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^i)ğ¸subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘–E(\widehat{\nabla}_{i}) or Eâ€‹(âˆ‡^j)ğ¸subscript^âˆ‡ğ‘—E(\widehat{\nabla}_{j}), respectively. Thus, they have to address it from other transmitted data. Note that since Nâˆ’|S|ğ‘ğ‘†N-|S| dropped clients would not join the model training, they are clearly unlikely to break the privacy guarantee, whether they collude or not. Therefore, we only consider the case that online |S|âˆ’2ğ‘†2|S|-2 curious clients (i.e., S/{ğ’i,ğ’j}ğ‘†subscriptğ’ğ‘–subscriptğ’ğ‘—S/\{\mathcal{C}_{i},\mathcal{C}_{j}\}) collude with the server for simplicity. 4.2 Fault-tolerant robustness of our scheme

Therefore, based on the correctness of recovering the aggregated gradient âˆ‡âˆ‡\nabla (see the Remark 1), our proposed scheme is robust for the dropped clients.

4.3 Comparison

In this section, we list the comparison of the privacy and fault tolerance for the state-of-the-art secure aggregation schemes in Table II, where âœ“and âœ• denote satisfied and unsatisfied, respectively. Before discussing the comparison result, we would like to briefly introduce these five schemes. Specifically, the schemes [14] and [30] are designed by the (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique, while both the scheme [8] and our scheme are presented based on the additive homomorphic encryption technique. The scheme [32] is introduced by combining these two techniques, where the (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique and the additive homomorphic encryption technique are used for private key distribution and secure additive aggregation, respectively. First of all, since the main purpose of secure aggregation in federated learning is to protect the local gradient, all schemes naturally meet the confidentiality of individual clients.

For three secret sharing-based schemes [14] and [30], since the (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique allows clients to select their own private keys and distribute the shares of the private key to other clients, both schemes meet the properties of no trusted third-party participation and client-defined private key. Besides, as long as receiving tğ‘¡t encrypted gradients, the aggregated result can be obtained. Thus, neither of the two schemes considers the decryption right of the aggregated result, i.e., anyone who obtains tğ‘¡t encrypted gradients can recover the aggregated result. As we all know, the (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing-based schemes have to face the trade-off between privacy guarantee against colluding clients (i.e., up to tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1 colluding clients) and robustness against dropped clients (i.e., up to Nâˆ’tğ‘ğ‘¡N-t clients). That is, these schemes increase the privacy guarantee by reducing the robustness against dropped clients and vice versa.

For two homomorphic encryption-based schemes [8] and [32], the scheme [8] needs to select the private key sâ€‹kğ‘ ğ‘˜sk shared among all clients, and thus the simplest way is to introduce a trusted third party to complete. The scheme [8] needs to select a pair of public and private keys shared among all clients, and thus the simplest way is to introduce a trusted third party to complete. The system initialization of scheme [32] selects a private key sâ€‹kğ‘ ğ‘˜sk and computes the corresponding Nğ‘N shares {sâ€‹k1,sâ€‹k2,â€¦,sâ€‹kN}ğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜2â€¦ğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘\{sk_{1},sk_{2},\ldots,sk_{N}\} by the secret sharing technique, and then distribute sâ€‹kiğ‘ subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–sk_{i} to the client ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i}. Obviously, in order to ensure privacy, it has to introduce a trusted third party to complete this operation. As a result, both schemes cannot satisfy the property without trusted third-party participation. Since all clients share a private key, the scheme [8] cannot satisfy the property of the client-defined private key, while similar to schemes [14] and [30], the scheme [32] meets this property. In addition, similar to [14] and [30], the scheme [32] cannot meet the decryption right of the aggregated result, while facing the trade-off between privacy guarantee against colluding clients and robustness against dropped clients. In [32], only clients have the shared private key, and thus only clients can decrypt the aggregation result, which means that the decryption right of the aggregated result is the clients. However, due to the shared private key, [32] cannot tolerate the collusion between the server and clients. That is, as long as one client is compromised, then other clientsâ€™ privacy cannot be guaranteed. Fortunately, this scheme can achieve robustness against up to Nâˆ’2ğ‘2N-2 dropped clients, which is more flexible than the other three schemes.

As shown in Section 3, the system initialization of our scheme is conducted by the server, and clients are free to choose their own public and private keys. Thus, our scheme satisfies the properties of no trusted third-party participation and client-defined private key. As analyzed in Section 4, the Theorem 2 demonstrates that only the server can decrypt the aggregated result, which implies that the decryption right of the aggregation result is the server. Besides, the Theorems 3 and 4 show that our scheme can resist up to Nâˆ’2ğ‘2N-2 colluded clients and tolerate up to Nâˆ’2ğ‘2N-2 dropped clients. Most notably, compared with the secret sharing-based schemes [14, 30, 32], our scheme would not face the trade-off between privacy and dropout-tolerant robustness.

5 Performance Evaluation

In this section, we discuss the simulation analysis and compare our scheme with the most related work [32] (called PCFL) as well as a non-private federated learning scheme (i.e., FedAvg [20]), in terms of model accuracy, computational costs and communication overhead. Specifically, we conduct experiments with the Torch libraries [33] running on an Ubuntu system equipped with an Intel Xeon CPU and TITAIXP GPU. In the simulation, we establish a federated learning system with 101010 clients to train a CNN model with MNIST dataset [34], Cifar10 dataset, and Cifar100 dataset, respectively. Each client trains the local model for 555 rounds with a learning rate of 0.010.010.01 prior to model upload. In our experiments, we set Îº1=512subscriptğœ…1512\kappa_{1}=512 bits and Îº2=256subscriptğœ…2256\kappa_{2}=256 bits for security requirements.

5.1 Comparison of training accuracy

We compare the training accuracy of our scheme to the PCFL [32] and FedAvg [20] under different epochs in Fig. 2. It can be seen from the figure that all three schemes converge almost within the same epoch, but the training accuracies for both our scheme and the PCFL [32] on MNIST, Cifar10, and Cifar100 are less than the non-private federated learning scheme FedAvg [20]. It is worth noting that neither our scheme nor the PCFL [32] theoretically loses accuracy since homomorphic encryption and secret sharing techniques are lossless privacy-preserving methods. However, by observing the figure, we can obtain that both our scheme and the PCFL [32] actually lose the training accuracy to some extent. This is attributed to the fact that local gradients are real numbers, while these privacy-preserving methods are carried out in an integer domain. In order to successfully implement the privacy-preserving methods in secure aggregation, it has to convert real numbers to integers, inevitably leading to precision loss during the rounding of real numbers [35]. Fortunately, this accuracy loss can be minimized by designing the appropriate conversion method, which will be discussed in our future work.

5.2 Comparison of computational costs

We depict the comparison of computational costs in Fig. 3. From the figure, it can be obviously shown that as the number of gradients increases (i.e., ranging in size from 10,000 to 40,000), the running times of both our schemes and the PCFL [32] are gradually increasing and larger than FedAvg [20]. Furthermore, compared with the PCFL [32], our scheme achieves almost 2x improvement in computational costs. It is well known that the introduction of privacy preservation inevitably sacrifices computational efficiency, which is why the running times of both secure aggregation schemes are larger than non-private FedAvg [20]. Most notably our scheme introduces a super-increasing sequence to compress multidimensional gradients into 1-D, which naturally greatly reduces the number of encryption and decryption operations. Roughly speaking, our scheme performs u=âŒˆnkâŒ‰âˆˆ[1,n]ğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘˜1ğ‘›u=\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil\in[1,n] 555Note that uğ‘¢u is usually much less than nğ‘›n since our scheme allows larger message space, resulting in a larger split interval kğ‘˜k. encryption and decryption operations, while the PCFL [32] has to perform nğ‘›n encryption and decryption operations. As a result, the computational efficiency of our scheme is much better than the PCFL [32].

5.3 Comparison of communication overhead

We plot the comparison of communication overhead in Fig. 4, which demonstrates that the communication overheads of both our scheme and the non-private FedAvg [20] are nearly equal, and are much smaller than the PCFL [32]. Furthermore, the communication advantage of our scheme becomes even more apparent as the number of model gradients increases. The main reason also owns to the introduction of the super-increasing sequence and the expansion of the plaintext space that can be processed for encryption and decryption. More specifically, because of the expansion of the plaintext space, the dimension that can be compressed is larger, i.e., kğ‘˜k becomes larger. Thus, when both nğ‘›n and kğ‘˜k increase, the growth rate of our schemeâ€™s ciphertext (i.e., the number of ciphertexts is âŒˆnkâŒ‰ğ‘›ğ‘˜\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil ) is obviously lower than the PCFL [32] (i.e., the number of ciphertexts is nğ‘›n).

Overall, the efficiency advantages of our scheme will become increasingly prominent as the number of model parameters increases compared with the state-of-the-art homomorphic encryption-based secure aggregation schemes.

6 Related Work

The concept of federated learning was first introduced by Google in 2016 [2] to address the privacy leak for distributed data providers. The core idea of federated learning is that under the orchestration of a central server, many distributed data providers (also called â€œclientâ€) collaborate locally to train a shared global model without uploading local training data to the data center [36]. The most popular implementation for federated learning has been proposed based on iterative model averaging, called FedAvg [20]. In FedAvg, many clients locally train the model with local data to obtain local gradient and send it to the server, and then the server aggregates (e.g., calculate the weighted average of local gradients) all received local gradients to update the global model. Afterward, many federated learning schemes [37] and implementations were presented based on the FedAvg. However, recent works [6, 7] have proved that federated learning still suffered from privacy leakage. For example, [6] showed that the adversary can reconstruct the training data from the transmitted local gradient.

In order to improve the privacy-preservation for training data of each client, many secure aggregation schemes for federated learning have been researched [8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 32, 14]. The corresponding core idea was that each client would encrypt the local gradient before uploading, and then the server conducted the aggregation on the encrypted gradients. As a result, the server could at most get aggregated results instead of each clientâ€™s local gradient. More specifically, these secure aggregation schemes were mainly designed by two cryptographic techniques: additive homomorphic encryption (HE) technique and (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique [18]. Unfortunately, these existing secure aggregation schemes faced many shortcomings, which greatly impeded their application in practice. For example, in the additive HE-based secure aggregation schemes [8, 9, 10, 11, 12], all clients shared a pair of public and private keys, and encrypted local gradient with the same public key. Obviously, once a client was compromised by the adversary, this system was no longer secure. To overcome this disadvantage, [38, 39, 32] considered assigning different keys to different clients, which allowed each client to encrypt the local gradient with its own public key by the same additive HE algorithm. Specifically, given a system private key, these schemes adopted the (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique to assign the different private keys to different clients. As long as more than tğ‘¡t clientsâ€™ encrypted gradients were aggregated, then the server can obtain the aggregated result. However, these existing HE-based schemes needed a trusted third party to complete key generation, and suffered from a huge computational cost and communication overhead, especially for the deep model with a large number of parameters.

In order to improve the efficiency, many secure aggregation schemes [14, 15, 16] only adopted (t,n)ğ‘¡ğ‘›(t,n)-threshold secret sharing technique. In these schemes, each client randomly selected two secret values as private keys and generated the additive shares for these two private keys. Then, they distributed the additive shares among each other. The local gradient was masked by these additive shares for privacy preservation. Obviously, these schemes permitted at most nâˆ’tğ‘›ğ‘¡n-t dropped clients or colluded clients. Furthermore, when no more than nâˆ’tğ‘›ğ‘¡n-t dropped clients exist, then the remaining online clients should upload extra secret shares to help the server to recover aggregated gradients. Unfortunately, when the number of clients is Nğ‘N, each client must store 2â€‹N2ğ‘2N secret additive shares. Furthermore, for different iterations, if two secret values were selected differently, then all clients must compute the corresponding additive shares and transmit them to each other. Obviously, this operation would increase the extra interactive time and communication overhead. If two secret values were reused for different iterations, then the corresponding additive shares could be computed and transmitted in the system-initialized phase, which could save much interactive time and communication overhead. However, the adversary could obtain the difference of local gradient for two different iterations, which may leak some private information for the local training data. Besides, these secret sharing-based schemes did not consider the privacy preservation of the aggregated result. That is, any adversary (i.e., not just the server) could obtain the aggregated result once getting the transmitted data.

As far as we know, designing an efficient secure aggregation scheme that supports client self-selected keys, robustness against collusion attacks, and fault tolerance robustness remains a challenge.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed an efficient and multi-private keys secure aggregation scheme for federated learning. Specifically, compared with most homomorphic encryption-based schemes, our scheme does not need a trusted third party to initialize the system. By skillfully designing the secure interactive protocol, our scheme achieves the additive homomorphic operation under the situation that clients freely select their own public/private key, which greatly improves the security of the whole system. Besides, by carefully modifying the variant ElGamal encryption and combing the super-increasing vector, our scheme can greatly expand the length of plaintext space and decrease the number of encryption/decryption operations as well as the number of ciphertexts. Detailed security analyses demonstrate that our scheme achieves the semantic security of both individual local gradients and the aggregated result while achieving optimal robustness in tolerating both client collusion and dropped clients. Further, extensive performance evaluations on three popular datasets demonstrate that our scheme outperforms the existing competing schemes in computational and communication efficiencies.
